title: How to Make Loose Green Tea Come Out Perfectly

steps.headline: Get your ingredients and prepare your equipment.
Ensure that everything is clean and ready for use.
Purify the water.
steps.description: Tap water might have a taste that affects the quality of green tea by affecting it's aroma and flavor. However, you can ignore this step if you are not in a hard water area.

steps.headline: Put a teaspoonful of tea per cup in the pot.
steps.description: Assume that a teaspoon is equivalent to 3 grams. It has been proved to be the best amount of green tea per cup for a high quality and natural tasting tea.

steps.headline: Pour a sufficient amount of water in the kettle and heat while examining the temperature of your water.
steps.description: The correct temperature should be within the range of 80°C to 85°C or 176°F to 185°F. This is because, when green tea is subjected to high temperatures like that of boiling water, it loses its natural taste and aroma.

steps.headline: Remove your water from the heat when it is about to boil.
steps.description: At this point, the temperature is around 93°C or 200°F. Or let the kettle boil and wait 3-4 minutes before pouring it over the tea.

steps.headline: Pour the hot water into your cup or teapot.
steps.description: After  passing through the procedure several times, you will be an expert  and enjoy the full natural taste of green tea. In addition, you will be  able to tell the difference between green tea of low quality and high  quality. Enjoy your cup of tea and stir it up!

text: Get your ingredients and prepare your equipment.  Ensure that everything is clean and ready for use.  Purify the water. Tap water might have a taste that affects the quality of green tea by affecting it's aroma and flavor. However, you can ignore this step if you are not in a hard water area. Put a teaspoonful of tea per cup in the pot. Assume that a teaspoon is equivalent to 3 grams. It has been proved to be the best amount of green tea per cup for a high quality and natural tasting tea. Pour a sufficient amount of water in the kettle and heat while examining the temperature of your water. The correct temperature should be within the range of 80°C to 85°C or 176°F to 185°F. This is because, when green tea is subjected to high temperatures like that of boiling water, it loses its natural taste and aroma. Remove your water from the heat when it is about to boil. At this point, the temperature is around 93°C or 200°F. Or let the kettle boil and wait 3-4 minutes before pouring it over the tea. Pour the hot water into your cup or teapot. After  passing through the procedure several times, you will be an expert  and enjoy the full natural taste of green tea. In addition, you will be  able to tell the difference between green tea of low quality and high  quality. Enjoy your cup of tea and stir it up! Finished.
